statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Stanford 84, Montana 66
article.story: STANFORD, Calif. (AP) -- Spending time on their home court has helped Dan Grunfeld and Chris Hernandez with their confidence. It's also helped on the scoreboard. Grunfeld scored 18 points and Hernandez had 17 in helping Stanford to its 18th consecutive home victory, an 84-66 win over Montana on Thursday night. "It takes time but we're working through it," Grunfeld said. "We ran our stuff and made our shots. It's always nice when you're playing at home in familiar surroundings. Like any good team we have guys who can shoot the ball." Tim Morris and Matt Haryasz each scored 11 for the Cardinal (6-4), who won their fourth straight overall. They have won 27 of their last 28 home games. The current streak is the longest active among Pac-10 schools. After playing its first seven games on the road, Stanford has put together its best stretch of the season at home, scoring more than 70 points in all three home games. "Without question this was our best game offensively," Stanford coach Trent Johnson said. "We had guys coming off the bench and shooting with confidence. We've got to continue to get better." Haryasz also blocked three shots to move into 10th on Stanford's career list with 64. He surpassed current Cardinal assistant Eric Reveno. Stanford also hit a season-high eight 3-pointers. Kevin Criswell scored 16 points to lead Montana (4-7), which lost its fourth in five games. Matt Martin added 14. "We had some foul issues we just couldn't overcome," Montana coach Larry Krystkowiak. "It was more like a football game where the offensive line wears down the defense. Stanford is very strong up front. We need to hit the weight room." Montana's only win in the four-game series came at Stanford in its last visit two years ago. The Grizzlies are one of just three teams since 1994 to win a nonconference game at Stanford. The Cardinal are 8-1 against the Big Sky Conference. Krystkowiak, the Grizzlies' first-year coach, played in the NBA for nine years and played for former Stanford coach Mike Montgomery, now with the Golden State Warriors, at Montana. "If the preseason doesn't kill us, we should be OK in the league," Krystkowiak said. "We had three tough games in California and learned a lot of lessons." Hernandez made his first two free throws when Krystkowiak was whistled for a technical foul, but then missed his next attempt late in the first half to end his consecutive streak at 16. The Cardinal maintained a comfortable lead through the second half, opening a 20-point edge with seven minutes remaining to play. Stanford raced to a 22-10 lead with 10:41 left in the first half following Haryasz' three-point play, and, after hitting three straight 3-pointers over the next two minutes, expanded its lead to as many as 18 before settling for a 49-36 advantage at halftime. It was the first time the Cardinal have held a double-digit halftime lead this year.
